importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article is updated on this date, marking the 21st day of the federal government shutdown, and discusses the potential for the shutdown to surpass the previous record of 35 days set during the first Trump administration.

This is the deadline for open enrollment of Obamacare plans. If the subsidies lapse, premiums are expected to double, which could influence Democrats’ decision to end the shutdown due to political consequences and public backlash against Republican inaction.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown is now on day 21 and could extend into early November, potentially surpassing the 35-day record. This timeline is critical because it reflects the growing duration and political tension, with public opinion shifts and policy impacts intensifying over time.

keyTakeAways: The federal government shutdown is the second-longest in U.S. history, currently lasting 21 days.
Democrats are winning the blame game in public opinion, with polls showing Americans blaming Republicans more than Democrats, despite Republicans making the policy demand.
The demand by Democrats to extend Obamacare subsidies is popular — 72% of Americans and 51% of Republicans support it — which gives Democrats political leverage.
Public opinion has consistently shown that Democrats are blamed less, with polling indicating a gap of 7 to 17 points in favor of blaming Republicans.

Historically, when Republicans make policy demands (like the border wall), they lose politically and give up. In contrast, Democrats are currently holding firm, despite popular support for their policy demand.
Key impacts of the shutdown include missed paychecks, delayed small business loans, and potential suspension of food stamps, which could influence public sentiment.
If the shutdown continues past November 1, rising health insurance premiums may push Democrats to back down, as they could claim Republicans are responsible for the cost increase.

The situation is more complex than past shutdowns because Democrats are not only politically strong but also aligning with popular policy preferences, creating a unique dynamic where they may hold out despite pressure.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Blake
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the author of the article and provides political analysis on the shutdown and blame dynamics between parties.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is central to the political blame game, claiming Democrats are 'getting killed in the polls' and accusing them of political wrongdoing.

namedEntities.name: Marjorie Taylor Greene
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She warns Republicans that they may be forced to come to the table due to fears of being blamed for rising health insurance premiums from subsidy cuts.

namedEntities.name: Reuters-Ipsos
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It conducted public opinion polls showing that Americans blame Republicans more than Democrats during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: CNBC
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It conducted a poll showing that Americans blame Republicans over Democrats by 53%-37% during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: NBC/Wall Street Journal
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It conducted pre-shutdown polling during the 1995–96 shutdown, showing initial public blame toward Republicans, which increased during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: KFF
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It reports that health insurance premiums could double if subsidies are not extended, a key concern for Americans and a potential leverage point for Democrats.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the policy under debate — the extension of enhanced subsidies — which is popular and politically significant, forming the core of Democrats’ demand.

namedEntities.name: 2018–2019 federal shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It serves as a precedent where Republicans made a policy demand (border wall) and lost politically, showing that policy demands from one party often lead to political backlash.

namedEntities.name: 1995–1996 federal shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is cited as a precedent where public blame shifted from Republicans to the GOP during the shutdown, leading to eventual compromise.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The federal government shutdown has reached its 21st day, the second-longest in U.S. history, with Democrats maintaining a strong political position by demanding the extension of Obamacare subsidies — a popular policy supported by 72% of Americans. Despite President Trump claiming Democrats are losing in the polls, public opinion polls consistently show Americans blaming Republicans more than Democrats, a reversal of historical patterns. This dynamic is unusual because, in past shutdowns, Republicans making policy demands lost politically. Now, Democrats are in a strong position due to both public support and policy alignment, raising the possibility that they might hold out until November 1, when open enrollment begins and premium hikes become tangible. If the shutdown continues, rising health costs could force Republicans to concede, especially if they fear being blamed for doubling insurance prices. The article highlights how this situation differs from past shutdowns, with Democrats not only holding political ground but potentially gaining significant political capital through persistence.
title: Could Democrats win the shutdown standoff? They’re still winning the blame game
